title: Stocks Gain on Hong Kong Hopes; Treasuries Decline: Markets Wrap
text:
(Bloomberg) -- Stocks in Europe and Asia climbed along with American index futures on hopes for a return to calm in Hong Kong. Treasuries slipped with the dollar.

Banks and retailers led gains on the Stoxx Europe 600 index as all 19 industry groups advanced. Contracts on the three major U.S. gauges rose. Shares in Hong Kong surged the most since 2018, helping markets across Asia to push higher, after reports that the city’s chief executive will withdraw a contentious extradition bill that sparked mass protests. The yen slipped amid the improved sentiment for risk assets. The pound strengthened along with U.K. stocks after lawmakers took a crucial first step to block a no-deal Brexit.

The formal withdrawal of Hong Kong’s extradition bill is one of the top demands of pro-democracy protesters who have demonstrated against the government for almost three months, weighing on markets globally. A return to calm would help lift investors’ mood after a key U.S. purchasing managers index indicated a contraction in American manufacturing in August, the latest in a slew of weak readings for factories around the world on Tuesday. The data caused traders to boost bets on deeper rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year.

Investors are alert for any news that China-U.S. talks are scheduled. Officials from both countries are struggling to agree on the next step after Washington rejected Beijing’s request to delay tariffs that took effect over the weekend.

Elsewhere, oil ticked higher and gold fell back. The onshore yuan rose after a stronger-than forecast daily currency fixing.

Here are some key events coming up:

Bank of England Governor Mark Carney speaks before Treasury Committee on Wednesday alongside colleagues Andy Haldane, Jonathan Haskel and Gertjan Vlieghe, on the bank’s August Inflation Report; he’ll then appear alone to discuss the U.K.’s economic relationship with the EU.Fed speakers this week include New York Fed’s John Williams on Wednesday and Fed chair Jerome Powell on Friday.The U.S. jobs report on Friday is projected to show the widely watched nonfarm payrolls rose by 160,000 in August, versus 164,000 the month prior. Estimates are for unemployment to be steady at 3.7% and the average hourly earnings rate of increase to slow to 3.0%.

These are the main moves in markets:

Stocks

The Stoxx Europe 600 Index gained 0.6% as of 8:07 a.m. London time.Futures on the S&P 500 Index advanced 0.8%.The U.K.’s FTSE 100 Index climbed 0.2%.The MSCI All-Country World Index increased 0.3%.The MSCI Emerging Market Index jumped 1.1%.

Currencies

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dipped 0.2%.The euro increased 0.1% to $1.0984.The British pound advanced 0.5% to $1.2141.The Japanese yen depreciated 0.4% to 106.14 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasuries advanced two basis points to 1.47%.The yield on two-year Treasuries dipped less than one basis point to 1.45%.Britain’s 10-year yield jumped three basis points to 0.442%.Germany’s 10-year yield gained two basis points to -0.69%.Japan’s 10-year yield was unchanged at -0.284%.

Commodities

West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.7% to $54.32 a barrel.Gold decreased 0.5% to $1,538.81 an ounce.Iron ore gained 2% to $87.42 per metric ton.
